metadata.title: Disasters: Famine, Water Scarcity, Volcano, Tsunami
metadata.subject: Science
metadata.description: This chapter covers natural and man-made disasters including famine, water scarcity, volcanic eruptions, and tsunamis, their causes, effects, and management strategies.

preAssessment.question: Which of these is caused by underwater earthquakes?
What is the main cause of water scarcity in many regions?
options: Overuse and unequal distribution of water

preAssessment.question: Molten rock that erupts from a volcano is called:
Which organisation issues tsunami warnings in the Indian Ocean?

concepts.title: Famine
concepts.content: A famine is a widespread condition in which many people in a country or region are unable to access sufficient food, leading to malnutrition, starvation, and death. Famines are caused by crop failures, drought, floods, war, or poor food distribution.

examples.text: The Bengal Famine of 1943 caused millions of deaths in India
Drought in sub-Saharan Africa causes frequent food shortages
Crop failure due to pests can trigger local famines

keyPoints.text: Famine is caused by a combination of natural and human factors
Effects include malnutrition, disease, and mass migration
Prevention involves food storage, fair distribution, and agricultural development

concepts.funFact: India has not experienced a major famine since independence due to the Green Revolution and improved food distribution systems.

concepts.title: Water Scarcity
concepts.content: Water scarcity occurs when the demand for water exceeds the available supply, or when poor water quality restricts its use. Only 3% of Earth's water is fresh, and much of it is locked in glaciers.

examples.text: Rajasthan in India faces severe water scarcity due to low rainfall
Cities like Chennai have faced water crises in recent years
Many African countries have limited access to clean drinking water

keyPoints.text: Only 1% of Earth's water is available as fresh water for use
Water conservation through rainwater harvesting can help
Overuse of groundwater leads to depletion of aquifers

concepts.funFact: A person needs a minimum of 50 litres of water per day, but billions of people have access to less than 25 litres!

concepts.title: Volcanic Eruptions
concepts.content: A volcano is an opening in the Earth's crust through which molten rock (magma), gases, and ash are expelled. When magma reaches the surface, it is called lava. Volcanoes can be active, dormant, or extinct.

examples.text: Barren Island in the Andaman Sea is India's only active volcano
Mount Vesuvius in Italy destroyed the city of Pompeii in 79 AD
Mount Kilauea in Hawaii has been erupting almost continuously

keyPoints.text: Volcanoes form along tectonic plate boundaries and hotspots
Volcanic ash can affect climate by blocking sunlight
Lava flows, pyroclastic flows, and ash falls are major hazards

concepts.funFact: Volcanic soil is extremely fertile! Many regions near volcanoes are great for farming because of the nutrient-rich volcanic ash.

concepts.title: Tsunami
concepts.content: A tsunami is a series of large ocean waves caused by sudden displacement of water, usually from underwater earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, or landslides. The word 'tsunami' is Japanese for 'harbour wave'.

examples.text: The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami killed over 2,30,000 people across 14 countries
Japan's 2011 T≈çhoku tsunami caused the Fukushima nuclear disaster
The coasts of Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh were severely affected in 2004

keyPoints.text: Tsunamis can travel at speeds up to 800 km/h in deep ocean
Warning signs: ground shaking, sea suddenly withdrawing from shore
Early warning systems can save thousands of lives

concepts.funFact: In deep ocean, a tsunami wave may only be 1 metre high and pass under ships unnoticed, but as it approaches shore, it can grow to over 30 metres!

concepts.title: Disaster Management
concepts.content: Disaster management involves the preparation, response, and recovery from disasters. It includes early warning systems, evacuation plans, relief operations, and long-term rehabilitation of affected areas.

examples.text: NDMA (National Disaster Management Authority) coordinates disaster response in India
Mock drills in schools prepare students for earthquakes and fires
The Sendai Framework is an international plan for disaster risk reduction

keyPoints.text: Four phases: Mitigation, Preparedness, Response, Recovery
Community awareness and training are key to reducing disaster impact
Technology like satellites and seismographs aid early warning

concepts.funFact: Japan holds the world's largest disaster preparedness drill every year on September 1st ‚Äî the anniversary of the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923.

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a cause of famine?
test.explanation: Heavy rainfall alone does not cause famine; drought, war, and crop failure are common causes.

test.question: What percentage of Earth's water is fresh water?
test.explanation: Only about 3% of Earth's water is fresh water, and most of that is locked in glaciers.

test.question: What is magma called when it reaches the Earth's surface?
test.explanation: Magma is molten rock underground; once it erupts onto the surface, it is called lava.

test.question: What does 'tsunami' mean in Japanese?
test.explanation: The word 'tsunami' comes from Japanese and means 'harbour wave'.

test.question: India's only active volcano is located in:
test.explanation: Barren Island in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands is India's only confirmed active volcano.

test.question: What is the main purpose of an early warning system?
options: To give people time to evacuate before a disaster
test.explanation: Early warning systems alert communities before disasters strike, giving time for evacuation and preparation.

test.question: The 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami was caused by:
test.explanation: The 2004 tsunami was triggered by a massive 9.1 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia.

test.question: Which practice helps conserve water at the community level?
test.explanation: Rainwater harvesting collects and stores rainwater for later use, helping address water scarcity.

commonMisconceptions: Volcanoes only occur in specific countries ‚Äî India also has one
Tsunamis are just big waves ‚Äî they are actually series of waves
Famine is only due to drought ‚Äî human factors also play a role

interactiveElement.description: Match each disaster type to its key characteristic.
